Summary of amendments/ record documents superseded by:
A new MSE policy to replace Broomfield hospital: 10114 - Urology

data.text: The aim of the Urology Service is to:

Provide high quality in-patient and out-patient facilities for patients requiring urological investigation and intervention. The service provides access to consultant urologists and specialist nurse teams via the Trust's out-patient clinics and provides both elective and emergency in-patient care.
Provide uro-oncology services, by links with specialist consultants within the Trust and also from Southend Hospital for pelvic cancer surgery and specialist nurses in the area of Uro- oncology.
Be responsive to in-patient consultation requests from other clinical teams to facilitate appropriate specialist management of urological conditions and expedite discharge.

To meet best practice guidelines in effective and efficient treatment of all urological conditions, both electively and emergencies to maximise outcomes by achieving the national standards set against them. The department aims to meet the national upper quartile Length of Stay for these conditions. The department aims to achieve the national standard for new to follow ups and day case rates within Urology Services.

As part of the sustainability MSE configuration the urology service is proposing a configuration with Broomfield and Basildon in order to create a 24/7 comprehensive regional urology service across mid and south Essex.
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The urology centre requires ease of access to IT, pathology, radiology and phlebotomy services and chemotherapy team and as such works closely with these services.
Radiology department Histopathology staff Nuclear medicine department;
Support from BME for servicing of equipment.
Clear defined departmental signage from the atrium to the urology centre;
Written directions are provided to the patients with their appointment letter.
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's IT policies;
Data sharing agreements will be drawn up to cover all data sharing outside the Trust in accordance with the Trusts' MSBPO-18003 Overarching Information Sharing Protocol;
Hospital information and patient data will only be downloaded onto devices provided by the trust which are encrypted;
Databases will be registered on the trust Information asset register via the Information Governance team - mse.informationgovernance@nhs.net;
Patient identifiable information will only be sent out of the Trust from an nhs.net account or other secure route;
Out of hours, the urology centre should be made secure.
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the trust's patient safety policies;
All staff must be screened through HR for a CRB check;
All staff must wear a name badge and carry a Trust ID;
All patients are chaperoned according to the Trust Chaperone Policy.
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Lone Worker; and Security policy; and Risk management policy.
Security for patients and staff – when necessary. Trust based security is available for patients and staff via the emergency phone / bleep numbers.
Flexible cystoscopy and renal ultrasound for haematuria.
Diagnostic Transrectal ultrasound guided biopsy for elevated PSA and abnormal rectal examination.
Diagnostic urodynamic & video urodynamic clinics confirming bladder outflow obstruction and bladder instability.
Catheter management clinics, providing services for GP's, theatres, medical and surgical wards.
Joint oncology clinics – supporting patients with new diagnosis of urological cancers.
Bladder instillation clinics for administering bladder chemotherapy and immunotherapy for bladder cancer and bladder instillations for interstitial cystitis.
Prostate assessment clinics for male lower urinary tract symptoms where uro-flow tests and post void scans are performed.
Adherence to all national guideline in respect to urological cancers and benign conditions.
Patient's notes must be available for clinic appointment.
Support from MBE for servicing of equipment.
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's IT policies.
Data sharing agreements will be drawn up to cover all data sharing outside the Trust in accordance with the Trusts' MSBPO-18003 Overarching Information Sharing Protocol.
Hospital information and patient data will only be downloaded onto devices provided by the trust which are encrypted.
Databases will be registered on the trust database of databases.
Patient identifiable information will only be sent out of the Trust from an nhs.net account or other secure route.
Out of hours, the urology centre should be made secure.

The MDT is a team of specialised clinicians working collaboratively to ensure a co- ordinated approach to treatment and care pathways for all patients diagnosed with urology cancer or pre-malignant disease. Any complex benign cases are discussed as well as management of recurrence and metastatic disease where appropriate.
All patients with a suspected urology cancer are discussed at the MDT following the clinic appointment, after surgery and after investigations.
The attendance at all meetings is recorded.
The core MDT members agree and record individual patient treatment plans in accordance with IOG guidelines.
A record of all patients discussed is kept in addition to the treatment plans.
Patients are recorded on the Somerset, the national database.
All patients diagnosed with a urological cancer will be allocated a key worker. All patients that attend a clinic appointment are sent a copy of the GP letter.
All patients have access numbers to key staff members such as the clinical nurse specialists, medical secretaries, MDT co-ordinator and admin co-ordinator.
Patients will receive written information from their consultation in preparation for their diagnostic tests and surgical procedures.
Dinamap V100 BP machine / Welch Albyn BP machine.
Printers – reception and medical secretary office.
Computers in all clinic rooms and offices.
Telephones in all clinic rooms and offices.
Clinics will run as normal as long as staff can get to work.
Extra clinics will be arranged for those cancelled.
Medical and senior nursing staff will have undergone advanced communication.
The urology clinicians support several cancer trials refer to Appendix 10.

data.text: All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Urology Consultant Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local urology guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Urology Consultant Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Who benefits from this change and how?
All urology service staff (nurses, consultants and doctors)
